text: This is a long shot type of question, but here goes. My great grandfather was a WWI Austrian prisoner of war who died in Sicily. Does anyone know how I could find his grave?

comments.comment_text:
I've been watching those shows on finding your roots.

Do you know what city in Sicily?

In Italy, by law after 30 years of being buried, if relatives do not ask for an extension of the burial "permit", bones are moved to the "ossuary", and the names of people buried there are not written anywhere, especially in smaller cemeteries.

text:
Hi All.
Doing the loop from Milan, Venice, Florence (not locked in yet) Vernazza, then back to Milan. Looking for some off the track lovely stops, but still accessible by train. We discovered montepulciano on our last visit and fell in love. Too out of the way for this trip but if we can find something similar from venice to Vernazza that would be perfect! Thanks 😊
PS will gratefully accept fave spots and must do’s anywhere on this route!

comments.comment_text: Padua not too far from Venice is great.

Verona or Lake Garda from Milan to Venice.Verona is home of Romeo and Juliet, and has the only roman amphitheater still used for Opera abd concerts (might want to check if you can find tickets, Arena di Verona).lovely stroll in the center to the river , many restaurant to choose from overlooking it.Take the cable car on the other side of the bridge and go up the hill..enjoy the view!
Lake Garda: you will stop in Desenzano.If you only have one day, take the bus from outside the train station to SIRMIONE.there is a medieval casale built on the water, beaches and many shops.If you have a couple of days, take the ferry from Sirmione and get to Riva del Garda or Malcesine.

Lake Garda is absolutely gorgeous(Malces
ine up the lake devine) or Sirmione busier but easier to get to and also lovely, porto Venere is beautiful near cinque Terre and we are going to visit Bergamo this year which I hear is lovely and not too far from Milan. Lucca between Vernazza and Florence another idea.
Lucca?

Lucca. Santa Margherita Ligure/
Portofino/
Camogli. Turin.
Bologna

Vicenza, Padova and Verona are all not far from Venice by train. Vicenza has many UNESCO villas by Palladio.

Padova has many sights including Prato della Valle. It's a 90,000-square-m
eter elliptical square in Padua, Italy. It is the largest square in Italy, and one of the largest in Europe. Also, book tickets online in advance for the Scrovegni Chapel. You won't be sorry.

Verona has many Roman ruins to include the Arena. Fun fact: if you go to the United Colors of Benetton in Via Mazzini, you won't go to shop. Head downstairs and you'll be greeted by Roman Ruins incorporated into the store.
What time of the year are you going?
From Milan to Venice you’ll pass through beautiful Verona - definitely worth a stop.
Treviso, Revenna, Bologna, Lucca, Pisa, Genova, Pavia, Torino. And then Pistoia, Pietrasanta, San Miniato, Bergamo, Mantova…

Levanto is just a few kilometers north of the Cinque Terre, and is a lovely small town. There is an old clock tower which still keeps perfect time, a beach, some amazing gelato and fun stores. You can also rent bikes and ride through an old train tunnel, right along the sea. It’s usually not crowded (I’ve been in March, May, and September) and I count it as one of my favorite places in Italy.

Hello,
Any one can tell me please if trainline show platform? Traveling from milan to trento on two different companies (trenitalia then italo) and need to save time

In regards to our September Italy tour I called our tour group to ask if we would get to see the inside of the colliseum or only the outside, also do we walk through the Roman Forum or just drive by? The website says “ panoramic” tour. The representative told us that usually yes, we get off the bus and enter the Colliseum and walk the Romanआणखी Forum. However she say this year is so overly crowded that they are having trouble getting tickets. She says if they can’t get us inside they will compensate with something else but we will still walk outside the colliseum walls and have a guided narrated history lesson.
We are disappointed to hear this as it’s our honeymoon and my first trip to Italy.
Anyone else experiencing trouble getting tickets? Even when it’s built into the Italy tour?

comments.comment_text: Getting tickets to the Colosseum this year are extremely difficult. There are a limited number per hour depending on your type and many vendors have been canceling tours as a result of not being able to secure tickets. If you want to ensure you go in, you may want to book your own tickets. Tickets are available 30 days ahead of your date and start loading on the Coopculture.it website at 9am local time and approximately every 15 minutes thereafter.

We're on a tour about the same time as you and, like you, I found the descriptions of "optional excursions" to be so vague that I called a representative who gave me even less info than you received. So I just started booking things on my own. Hubby and I aren't interested in a drive by colosseum tour, so I booked our own. I've learned so much about these tours, and that you don't really get alot of detail until just a few weeks before, which just doesn't sit well with me. Anyway, we are going to have a beautiful, romantic and forever memorable vacation to Italy and will likely not do a whole lot with the tour other than a roof over our head and transport from one city to the next. Enjoy!
Book on your own
Go to Verona and take in an opera or similar event at the exquisite arena there.

text: Going on a Mediterranean cruise middle of September for 3￼weeks. What is the weather like and what should I wear?
We are traveling from US with kids and are not going to check in any bags. Is it possible to buy sunscreen spray in Rome? If so, what kinda place?thanks

comments.comment_text: Supermarkets have cheaper options (Nivea, Bilboa, sometimes the supermarket brands, Angstom…), pharmacies usually have more expensive brands.
You could each carry 3oz worth on the plane until you find it in a store.
Farmacia
Yes. Everywhere
I brought a CVS sunscreen stick (70 spf) before I traveled to Italy. It is the size of deodorant and worked great and doesn'ttake up much space. Highly recommend.
Try to find solid sunscreen sticks before you go. Sunscreen is very expensive in Italy.
We bought some at the supermarket and it was far better than what we can get in US.
Any farmacia
Rome is a very cultured city…they have everything and more

Yes you certainly can but what you can't get are the massive containers of very high SPF that the Aus supermarkets sell very cheaply. If I pack a hold case I do always put one of those in - double wrapped and sealed.
Italian skincare products are the best in the world!
Any Farmacia or supermarket.

If not comfortable buying in Italy (the pharmacy and convenient store will have them), consider getting the sunscreen stick from Amazon, they are travel size. One stick should be enough for two kids. These are the two I used for my kiddos.
Every pharmacy on every corner. I got a sunblock with a free after sun moisturizer and the moisturizer is my fave!

Each person traveling can bring quart sized ziploc baggie with all 3.4oz or less liquids in the ziploc inside your carry ons. This is allowed through TSA security checkpoints. I bought this sunscreen at dollar tree store, and it’s 3oz.

text: Hello! My husband and I were going to utilize the bus system to see the Sistine Chapel, Colosseum, St. Peter’s Basilica etc… when we visit in mid September. Is it slower then for that to be a good option? Or should we do a guided tour?

comments.comment_text: It’s how we did it. Very easy

If you are able just walk. Most of the things you want to see in Rome are under a mile and you get to take in all the sights and places you would miss if you were in a car or bus. When we were there we just Google maped the walk time and started a little early in case we wanted to stop for some reason, coffee, food, unknown cool places we happened upon.
We taxi’d between the necessary points from our apartment. You can also take the metro.
We used the metro... very easy

Supereasy by metro or bus. You can buy daily tickets//48h/
72h or 1 week at Metro stations. Colosseo is a metro stop and the Vatican Museum too. With the bus/metro passes you can only hop on and off city buses, when I am too tired and see a bus stop (they are big and yellow or green) I check if any of those buses will take me to Colosseo/
Termini or whatever other metro station I need, even if it is a detour and hop on the first not crowded bus I see.

1. I used one carry-on backpack for myself. Cotopaxi Allpa 42L. I loved this because it is a backpack (easy to carry around) that opens like a suitcase when you lay it down. I packed light and did not fill the backpack. I easily could have gotten the smaller 35L size - that would have worked even better for me with a little less weight and size. I was able to get away with the 42L size by keeping it light. I think if I had been on a discount international airline, they would have made me check it. A 35L would fit their guidelines. 2. My husband and youngest son used Osprey Fairpoint 40. Those worked well. 3. My oldest son used REI Ruckpack 40L. My husband said he liked that one best because of how much wider it opened at the top than the Osprey.
Monos carry on Plus

Naples isn't for everyone. If you like life, bustling realism, pizza, street art and tons of things to visit (over 100 sites in the city are scoring a minimum 4/5 on Trip Advisor), then it's worth a go. Some prefer 5***** hotels, expensive tours, and never without AC exclusivity. Naples probably won't appeal. I would select 2, 3, or 4 of my own researched priorities, as I assume you know what you're more likely to enjoy, then Pompei and then a day on an island by boat - Capri if you want to, but see your options and choose your preference. I prefer my own research. I rarely listen to opinions as they're often too subjective, more money than sense, or plain wrong. OK, if 100 out of 100 say Naples is a dump, then I'll take some note. comments.comment_text: Unless it is pasta all’uovo pasta has no eggs in it

If it is not specified,Dried
pasta (penne,fusilli,
spaghetti)does not contains eggs. Pasta usually contains eggs (whole or parts) when it is handmade, but not all restaurants do that. Also, it is more common to find tagliolini,tagl
iatelle but also ravioli and tordelli with eggs
As a note, many restaurants in Italy use a number system for allergens and are excellent about labeling.
It is mandatory by law in every restaurant to have the list of allergens on the menu.

Join our local guide Patrizia in the exploration of this hidden gem as she walks through Spello’s crooked streets, ancient city gates and pink stone houses. Skip Naples and stay in Sorrento as a base You can visit Pompeii, Herculaneum and Mount Vesuvius and also hit the Amalfi Coast from Sorrento. Sorrento is a beautiful town on the coast and not as crowded either especially during October.

Oplantas is small but much more beautiful then Pompeii and much less crowded. The Suberban bath in Herculaneumis is very cool and all the skeletons of people who died there are just down below the bath.
La Sicilia è grande, ottobre è un mese fantastico per venire in Italia. In Sicilia vai ancora in spiaggia

Can’t speak for Naples because in the heat, we couldn’t see past the port area which looked like downtown LA to me. I hear it’s great though.

Sorrento & Florence were our favorites! So warm & welcoming… Sorrento is so quaint!

Sicily should be a completely separate trip. We spent 12 days there and regreted not budgeting a few more. And just seeing Tauromina is not "doing Sicily. It's crowded and touristy, unlike the rest of Sicily.

I like the real Italy.. the small unknown areas.Rome,Mila
n,Florence Naples..yes they are all beautiful but too busy for me..like the small mountain villages. Getting to know the locals..oooohhh
and the Food!!!!!.....n
ot good for the waistline haha
Following

A region that foreign people usually forget is Puglia, if you are talking about south Italy.
Great sea, great food and wines.
Bari deserves a visit, so the Salento area.
Ostuni is wonderful, Otranto is pretty nice as well. Than it depends a lot by what you like to do and all the country is interesting and beautiful.
I agree with some other people that commented about do the REAL Italy. Is nice to see the highlights but if you have time and the opportunity try to do something different
Frolence and Cisily are totaly different

I would get outside of Florence. There are a ton of charming towns that are easy to day trip to other areas. We are in Siena now and not crowded and very enjoyable in the evenings.

Sorrento was crowded. Maybe not when you are going though.

Definitely do Sicily- loved Messina and a little very authentic Italian town named Pozzallo- if you don’t want crowds or stress and want a real Sicilian experience that’s a place I recommend. Happy Home is the BnB apartment to book - magnificent!

Absolutely right..The unknown places in italy have souch to offer.. I have had some amazing trips to beautiful places in italy.i go to the same village every year.i have lived and worked in England all my life.So when I go to italy it's like a different world.so relaxed.

We went last October and only did Emilia Romagna. We went to Bologna, Modena (our favorite)and Rimini. We did not stay in airbnbs, we stayed on hotels. We became a local for 2 weeks and it was wonderful.
Montecatini a spa town west of Firenze

text:
Looking for some advice from experienced travellers 😎

We are coming from the UK and looking at 7-8 days Amalfi and Tuscany in October, not interested in Rome this trip. Do you think these two destinations are doable in this time frame? Should we visit one before the other? I’ve looked at different airports and it doesn’t bother us which we do first, just trying to work out at the least travel time. Has anyone travelled between these two locations from the UK?

comments.comment_text: Fly into Naples, local train to Sorrento then bus to Amalfi, depends what you want to see? then you have to get back to Naples fast train to Florence a lot of Kilometres or miles travelling , myself I would spend the time in Sorrento doing day trips to Capri, Positano, Amalfi 🌻

Short trip duration, long dull time to travel from Florence to Amalfi, or Naples to Florence. I wouldn't. I'd do one or the other. Florence and close by. Or Amalfi/Naples and Amalfi, close by. Be nice to relax not just stopping a day or two, packing up and travelling again, repeat. Plus you're going in October when things on the coast will be restricted.

For 7 or 8 days I would choise one destination. In the south you have Naples, Capri, Anacapri, Pomoei, Vesuvio, Amalfitana, Sorento..
In Tuscany also so much to see - Florence, Siena, S.Gimignano, Pienza, Bagno vignoni, Cortona, Pisa, Lucca, Montepulciano….
.

From naples to florence the high speed train takes 3 hours. You will miss half day traveling. I advice to visit naples, amalfi coast and capri or Ischia ( beautiful volcanic island with baths terms in front of Naples)

Hiya also from UK. I’d do 1 or the other & suggest Tuscany. Fly to Pisa go & spend a couple of days in Lucca - 30 mins by train or take a taxi to Lucca. Then go to Florence & base yourself there for 2/3 days in Florence itself & day trips to sienna, San Giminiano & surrounding area. Do Naples/
Sorrento etc when you have another 8 days spare. Happy hols!

text:
Hi all,
We are thinking of traveling to italy in the beggining of octocber with our 2 year old.
Can anyone share thier experience with the weather that time of year and suggest where would be best to be? Thanks 😍

comments.comment_text: It's still warm in the south, especially in Sicily. As you move up the peninsula, it gradually gets colder but even in Milan the weather should be fairly good at the beginning of October. I'd say it's one of the best months to travel to Italy, more or less everywhere in the country.

text: Today Italy travel tip🤗Roma world theme park….I have not been but looks cool

Helloo i am planning to visit Milan city in august. I am staying near city center of milan. I would like to know about safety issues. Milan city center is safe to stay ? Thanks in advance.

comments.comment_text: Yes it's safe. Obviously there is some pickpockets as in all cities so just pay attention like you would anywhere else. August is when most Italians have holidays so a lot is shut. Metro, bus, trains are all ok. Walking is fine too
Much safer than in Paris, anyway always pay attention to your belongings, never leave your bag or phone on a table or chair like in every big cities

Some visit ideas : Duomo, navigli, Cenacolo, botanical garden, galleria VE II, castello Sforzesco, art nouveau, street art porta Ticinese, basilica San Lorenzo, rooftop bar at Rinascente with view on the Duomo, make sure to book well in advance for the Cenacolo. I stayed at hotel Gran Duca di York it was nice and central.

Why Milan?in August?the least favorite Italian city by Italians.sorry,
just being honest.
I use the App TRIPIT , it will give you a safety rating on the different location you are going .. eg .. your Hotel it will give you near by restaurant , attractions, trains and other
The only place I was ever concerned about safety anywhere in Italy at any time was near the central railway station in Rome. Other than that I never gave it a thought at all, Italy is safe.

text: We booked train tickets through Trainline app from Florence to Sienna. Three questions, how do we get from airport to Santa Maria Novella station and how do we know which train to get on? Our ticket just says time and destination so I’m assuming we don’t have assigned seats? Thx!

comments.comment_text: Santa Maria is the main station in Florence. Take a train from airport to Florence Station and there you will change to a train for Sienna. Your ticket will definitely have a train number- you will check on the board, according to your routing and time, which platform to go to. The train number will appear there too. Sometimes the trains come up on the board less than half an hour before departure- keep an eye on the boards, or ask staff.
The tickets will have a train number Find that on the departure board. (2nd column from left) They post the platform about 10-15 minutes prior to departure. (Second to last column on the right).
How do you catch a train where you live ?

text: Hi, trying to book some accommodation for Rome end of August and I'm going round in circles! Any recommendations please?? 🙏
Any advise or tips on best way to deal with the heat wave? We're headed to Italy AUG 5th - 17th, trying to figure out best way to prepare....thanks

comments.comment_text: I just left. Start early in the morning to your excursions. Most streets are narrow offering some shade. Carry a water bottle every where. When I went to pompei I put a wet hankerchief around my neck. Have a hat!
After doing that once I said never again. Spring or fall for me now

Nothing can physically prepare you for the heat here at present - just bring refillable water bottles, umbrella/hand held fan, hats loose clothing and plenty of deodorant! Try not to book any tours between 11-3 go early or late
Next fan!

We just got back on Sat. It was hot, I’m not going to minimize that. We did skip some stuff, like we did the colosseum tour but skipped the forum and palatine hill. We did stuff as early or later in the day if possible and tried too nap at the hotel during the day when possible. I definitely had to adjust for the heat.

We are all hoping that August will be a little cooler. In the north of Italy at the moment I believe temperatures have dropped a little. If you are lucky your holiday won't be affected by the heat wave, or at least it won't be as hot as July
Where in Italy ? The heat wave never lasts for weeks
Rest inside between 1pm - 6pm.
Take Pepto Bismal chewable- summer diarrhea is a thing.
Do mornings and nights and take shelter mid day lol
Linen long clothing, stay hydrated, sun block, stay out of the miday heat if you can go to museums, go to McDs they havr aircon hats ,umbrellas

We always have wet wipes to cool off quickly and often. We have been using all the tips given. It’s hot. Be prepared to do things but in a different order than originally planned. Take breaks. Also rehydrate with water and electrolytes. Otherwise you’ll get dizzy. You can get gatorade or something else. Just something to replace the salt your sweating
I'm thinking you'd prepare much like you would at home when it's that hot! 😉

I am currently in southern Italy and see that the weather will improve over the next few days already. I do agree though that it is best to stay in an air conditioned area in the early afternoon until about 5-6 pm. It is extremely hot during that period and not pleasant to be outdoors.
Bring bug spray from US. Last year in August folks were miserable. The Italian products do not work as well
Drink plenty of water. There's nowhere to hide when it's 110°
It doesn’t look too bad. The high in Como on the 2nd is only 73!!!
I got cooling clothes from Amazon. They do help, you need to keep getting them wet, but worth it. I’m here in Italy now.
We booked hotels with pools. Toured 7am til about 2 then hung at the pool til 6. Showered and ventured back out for the eve.
Heat wave ended last Thursday, at least here in the north.
Cool towels and Gatorade. Can get it in powdered mix.
Gab Katya Sandler: maybe to late for you but was recently in the Alps. Mid 70s while people were cooking in Rome, Florence, etc. Also some of the most breathtaking scenery in Italy.
I plan July or Aug … any benefit to either time next year if one better than the other?
Lots of wine cellars and stay at Agriturismo’s with pools…also Lemoncello Spritzers!

🙄😫🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣
do you know any weather magic tricks??? It’s Summer AUGUST hot everywhere .. Omg so silly but thanks for the laugh 👍👍
We were there this week. Walk in the shade as much as possible, drink plenty of water, take breaks, visit museums and churches, where a wide brim hat.
A wet washer on the back of the neck does wonders.
Wear light clothing, especially linen. Keep out of the sun between 10 and 2.
I would bring a small rechargeable fan. The hotels can be very warm and when you have been out in the heat all day, you will appreciate a cool room.
The mini rechargeable fans were life savers in Rome two weeks ago! Also, we brought collapsible water bottles and filled them with cold water from the fountains. Linen clothing!
Buy neck fans off Amazon.
We froze half full water bottles over night so we had cold water during the day. There are fountains around, but they aren’t always very cold.

Portable fans, freeze your water and also Gatorade to replenish electrolytes. I don’t think I’ve ever sweat so much in my life as I have here these last 2 weeks. Loose, flowy clothing…. Linen is great.
Turn off your AC here to acclimate to higher temperatures. Go out walking now to prepare for the walking in hot weather.
Get up early and go- then rest- go out at night. Lots of water to keep hydrated.
I bought cooling towels on Amazon. They work great! Spent 4 hours walking around Pompeii ruins yesterday. Very tolerable with that on my neck.

Start your day early, have lunch somewhere nice and cool. Use central hours to visit some place with AC, get back to your place for a short nap then get ready for dinner. Avoid wine during the day, stay hydrated, cover your head whenever in the sun, dress comfortable in linen or cotton.
Next fan!

Linen clothing, personal fan possibly with mister, hats, sunglasses, sunscreen(sport
sunscreen isn’t oily or runny), go/book any sightseeing early, back in hotel from 3-7, the. Go back out for dinner and night time sightseeing. We survived 7/4-15

text:
Need advice from those with teens on how they keep them and the PEACE By making sure phones worked on vacation without breaking the bank. We have Verizon in the states and iPhones.

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE

comments.comment_text: Following
Get DIGI sim card, available from TIM or other stores. We bought the physical SIM that has 20 GB plus local calling for 15 euro
Can't you just get a local SIM? Depending on the plan, you'll typically get unlimited data for less than 20€ per month
When I was in Portugal last summer I bought a portable mifi device from Vodafone. $50 euros and include 15 days of data

A mobile hotspot/
wireless portable wifi is the best way to go and most practical. Check with your carrier, they should offer it, Amazon sells them too and you just buy the data. Or get an international plan then the kids can connect by turning on the hotspot from your phone.

If they need data only, and have recent phone models, use the app Airalo. You won’t find a lower cost way to get them
Data. If they need phoning and texting then get a local sim. We paid €25 each for 70gb, texting and calls when we were there earlier this month. Got them at Rome airport
Following
My husband and I had the international plans for $100 a month. Teens were fine with wifi in the hotel. We were always busy and on the run and it gave us their attention as well :)
You are also dealing with a time difference so that kind of worked in our favor too
$10/day Verizon
Airalo is great!!
We’re here 3 weeks … Verizon month plan $100….do the $10 a day if u wish … $50 SIM cards work too

I had just switched from Verizon to spectrum before my family’s trip to Europe last year… there were 5 of us on one plan- and the price for data was very reasonable! It varied slightly by country- but our 12 day stay cost me an additional $80 that month …. And all of us were using google maps, apps to maneuver public transit, social media- like Snapchat- and other online resources, like google translate. Call your service provider, they’ll walk you through what you need to do. I believe Verizon charges a daily fee for data .
I’d make them just use it when you’re under Wi-Fi. Turn it on airplane roams and turn off data roaming.
We paid $100/per line and paid too much money but I think it was worth it.

My husband got the Verizon 10$ day international plan. He can use the Google maps and look up restaurant reviews and train times.
My phone is in airplane mode non stop. I connect to wifi on trains. At the hotel and at 1 restaurants. There is no time to be on social media. I just take all of the photos! Only your main lead traveller needs international access.

We have Verizon at home. We used esim cards from airarlo while traveling earlier this summer. Can’t make actual calls or texts, but you can through WhatsApp at no additional charge. Worked great for us.
Once you arrive go to vodaphone and buy a new sim. Unlimited everything for quite cheap !!!
Airalo

text: Would we be crazy to do a day trip to Pisa from just outside Verona?? Have a car and would leave around 8am. Google maps is saying it would take just under 3 hours to drive. Where would we park? Any idea on toll prices? Kids just want to see the tower.

comments.comment_text: Pisa is not worth it. Worst tourist trap in Italy. Everywhere else we went in Italy was great.

Sincerely Pisa is just the leaning tower and that’s it more or less. From Verona you can spend your day in menu more ways.
You can do a round trip around Garda lake, visit dolomites or some wine area: Treviso is a really nice city for example and you have valdobbiadene unesco area just half an out away from it.
I mean if your dream it’s to go to Pisa go ahead, but it doesn’t make sense to me

Honestly there are more beautiful sites than Pisa. It was my least favorite part of my trip. Getting through the guantlet of people selling items on the sides of the street was overwhelming and unwelcomed. And I mean literally laid out on the pavement on the side of the roads leading into Pisa. Put this on your back burner and go when you're staying closer to the area.

Not worth the drive in my opinion. Use the time to go to Lake Garda or even Venice. You can park the car near the train station. Or better yet, just do the train from Verona to Venice and spend your time there.
Go to Bologna that has a more leaning tower than Pisa
Not crazy at all, Pisa is a really small town and one day there would be perfect.

Lol actually I’m staying in Florence. Yesterday my son and I took the train to Lucca and decided to take a train to Pisa before heading back to Florence. I have to say I’m glad we did. We were there about 7ish not insanely crowded. Found a nice place to eat before we took the train back to Florence. I don’t know if I’d drive 3 hours to get there but I’m glad we made the mini detour
You only need half a day there so go for it !
Pisa (especially the tower) is NOT worth that amount of effort. Save your precious day for something else, and do something closer to you.
We just drive to Pisa and parking was easy and very close to the tower. If the kids want to do it — go for it!

Toll is 22€ each way - here for the toll calculator https://
www.autostrade.i
t/it/
traffico-in-real
-time.
I would personally consider the trip insane but it's really an individual choice: in the 6 hours minimum for the return trip (consider right now Google maps is saying 5 hours due to congestion) I'd look for something else closer to Verona but indeed if you have the leaning tower as one of things not to be missed just go for it!👍

You just need a few hours in Pisa. We took the train from Florence around 5 pm and were back to Florence a little earlier than midnight and that included as much sightseeing as we wanted to do and a wonderful dinner.
Not worth it, no way!! Take them to a beach instead.

If you are interested I wrote a post here about Pisa so the day is worth it and not just an useless photo to a leaning tower (search in the group with the lens). Actually Pisa is really nice only if you don’t visit it like a sheep tourist who look on google maps for the faster way to the leaning tower!
Train?

To me going to Italy, and not seeing the leaning tower is like going to Paris and not seeing the Eiffel tower. They are kids, I say go for it you won’t regret it. True, the only thing to see is the leaning tower’ JMHO… I insisted my family should see it when we were in the area and I don’t regret it to this day. Every time I look at the pictures of my grand kids holding up the tower.
Don’t waste your time driving to Pisa. Instead drive to Lago di Garda or Vicenza or Padova. Much more to see than the Piazza di Miracoli? JMO.
If it’s something you really want to see go for it! Only thing is if it’s in august good luck! Parking , tourist, heat, etc 😳
If it’s something you want to do as a family go for it.
Not worth a 3 hour drive IMO.
So many other places to go that would be better than Pisa. If you are itching to drive how about Bologna and Parma?

We loved going to Pisa. We walked around the town and had the best gelato! We got tickets and walked to the top. If you go and want to walk up to the top of the tower. Get your tickets first so you know what time to get in line. I loved looking around and seeing every nationality taking the same picture with the tower. Very touristy thing to do but it was a great time. You could maybe be there 2 or 3 hours. Then find another place. We drove to Lucca. Another great town!

You would be crazy not to do Verona from just outside Verona. 😏 Kidding Verona is lovely but if you went by rail from Verona Station to Pisa you would really enjoy the walk from station to the leaning tower and Church. Nice architecture, city wall, shops etc, most don’t see Pisa.
The leaning tower was not much to see
Lucca is very nice. Pisa look at the tower and the church next to it, est a pizza looking at it, and that’s it
I find Pisa underwhelming. If I was in Verona I would do Lake Garda, Dolomites or Venice!! Bologna is superb too!!
Stop in Lucca and then a quick stop at Pisa. Yes, it’s the only thing there, but it’s beautiful. And if you are going to Lucca it’s close and then just head back.

text: Thank you admin for allowing me to join this group. We are looking at planning a 3 week trip in September/ October and the amount of tips etc on this group is amazing!!

Warning - I bough a necklace for my daughter in Florence and it broke into pieces. I couldn’t believe it. I honestly don’t remember the name of the store, but my credit card and tax form says Old Bridgeआणखी Gallery… I’m sure some of their pieces are fine, but costume jewelry holds up better than this. This was a necklace and we bought it a week ago. She was wearing it and it broke in the pool.

comments.comment_text: Call your credit card company. I bet they will dispute the charge & reverse your payment. It may take a few weeks to process. But, with this pic; you def have a legit case. Best of Luck 🤞

You are not in Florence any more I guess.
Sorry to hear this, but it was supposed to be....gold?
Wanted to get an Italian gold chain when visiting, now I’m not sure! 🤔
Is it supposed to be real gold?
dispute it
Oh I would definitely dispute that with your credit card company. That’s just horrible!
That’s bizarre ! It broke into all those tiny pieces? Are you sure she didn’t snag it on something? How on earth did you get all those pieces from the pool?
Is it gold?
I would have it tested locally to see if it was really gold. So bizzarre.

I’ve ran a jewelry store for 20 years and unfortunately this can happen, especially with chlorine. Chemicals can make the gold brittle where it falls apart, especially if the chain wasn’t solid. It looks like it was probably semi-hollow and if it was lightweight this can happen. Still call your credit company or the store because you’re well in warranty but just wanted to say from a jeweler it does happen.

How did it snap
into so many little pieces?

I bought a leather belt in Florence that came apart before I got home. My husband super glued it back together, but it was not cheap. Jewelry leather ect, thank is not cheap. Just be aware of what you are buying
Must be fake gold! 😱🥲
It’s due to the chlorine
Where the loops are welded was eaten away by the chlorine probably
It's not very good quality to start with but, also I never wear jewelry in a pool for fear of what the chlorine might do to it.
That’s sad
Its not gold. I have work my gold necklace for 5 years and never removed it. Has never broken or been damaged. In pool, in spa, ocean or anywhere. Sorry u got tricked looks like it
I have one like that I got 30 years ago and still wear it everyday.
I prefer to buy jewelry in my country PERÚ, is much better material in GOLD and SILVER.

“It's not just chlorine that can damage your gold jewellery and diamonds; saltwater can damage them too. Salt causes erosion of soldered gold, silver or platinum elements. As a result, the precious metal may weaken meaning your jewellery could potentially break. The diamonds can also get blemished by salt.”
Just the name of the shop should have been enough of a red flag. There are numerous shops close by the train station in Milan where necklaces just like that can be had for as little as 5 euros.
I don’t think it was gold I wear mine everyday and when I go swimming in the pool

text: Does anyone have details about breakfast at Aroma? Looks like they start serving at 7:30am and couldn’t tell imom the website if they do reservations for breakfast or not.

Hello new in this group and for a week mow been reading almost all the posts here and you guys are so helpful. We are arriving via cruise ar Civitavecchia and we are planning to go to Rome and Bellagio in Lake Como then flying out of Milan. We are Looking for suggestions for trains or renting a car from Civitavecchia if you are me which optionsआणखी would you go first timer here. Also in Rome do you guys have a kist of website where we can pre purchase all tour tickets (Vatican, Colosseum, etc?) would be nice if an admin of this group could create a doc for recommendations like trains, tour tickets, etc all in one place. Any help is greatly appreciated please and thank you.

comments.comment_text: We just got back from 5 weeks in Paris and Italy. We downloaded the Get Your Guide app and we booked all our stuff through there . It saves your tickets etc. Everything in one place .

Trenitalia for trains
Tiquets, get your guide or viator for tours or direct through the sites own website is sometimes cheaper - but choose skip the line !

Before you leave the old city “civilavecchia”
visit the Etruscan necropolis. It has some of the most amazing Etruscan tombs in Italy.

I suggest you don't try to drive or park in the center of Rome, only insiders know where you can legally drive, like taxis. It is best to arrange a taxi or private car from the ship, or take the train into the city. From Rome, fly to Milan, spend a few days there to see the important sights, then take the train the l hr. train ride to Lake Como - get off at Varenna, where you can take the ferry around the lake for sightseeing. See the great video on Rick Steves website "Milan to Lake Como" for details on hotels, etc. Get tour tickets in Rome by going to the websites for the Vatican, etc.
Trains will likely be less expensive.

text: Hi there. I would love to purchase a gold Roman coin pendant, but have no idea where a reliable jeweler may be located in Rome. Any thoughts?

Help! My luggage has been lost since Monday and I can’t get the Venice Airport or Ryanair to tell me what airport my bag is even at. Is there any hope at this point? I’ve called both and just keep getting the runaround 😞

comments.comment_text: They'll find it eventually, just make sure to submit all your receipts for your new clothes, shoes, suitcase, toiletries etc. Do not allow them to tell you they'll only give you $150. AND, make sure they know your next hotel/ destination. We had told them we were leaving Florence on a Tuesday after our bag was lost the prior Friday. Since we were renting our car at the airport, I figured I'd check again and after they talked to eo, one went to the truck in the back and came out with my bag! They had found it, didn't tell me and they were going to deliver it to the airbnb we had already checked out of. Good luck!
Darren Bonaccorso, AirTags!
Don't travel without air tags

Happened to us years ago. All I can say is to still enjoy the trip-buy underwear and a couple shirts. They kept saying our luggage was found so much of the trip was waiting for the luggage. Just give in. Sorry it happened.

This juts happened to my family! We flew Houston to Amsterdam, layover, Amsterdam to Venice. Of the 8 people we traveled with 6 bags were lost. 3 airtags showed the bags were in Venice the next day so my dad literally went back to the airport and had an airport worker take him to the “lane of the lost luggage” and he found the bags himself. 2 days later 2 more bags arrived and they actually delivered them to our hotel in Venice (KLM airlines). The last bag stayed in Amsterdam for 5 days, arrived in Venice, stayed there 4 days, went to Paris where it never got delivered to our future hotel, and then went back to Venice. We ended up getting it this week, via currier from Houston airport, 3 weeks to the day we lost it 🙈. Thankful it was not lost forever but unfortunate it never arrived with all of my husbands things and our extra toiletries. KLM said they would give up to 500.00 if you saved receipts and filed a claim. We will see if that happens. So sorry this happened to you.

They told us It’s tough to check bags there right now as it is so so busy and they have limited staff to return the luggage once it is found.

text: Hello. This has been such a helpful group. We are flying into Rome in September and would love comments about how to travel from Rome airport to Sorrento. Rent a car or get a private driver or take a train? Any info on the three would be greatly appreciated!

comments.comment_text: Most people will probably say train from Rome to Naples then private driver from there. After doing this recently though, if I was flying in and then immediately going to Sorrento I’d opt for a private driver the whole way if cost isn’t an issue just cause you’ll be exhausted when you land and it’ll be convenient 🤷🏽‍♀️ though the train is very easy, but that’s just what I would do personally! If you’re staying in Rome for a couple of days first, I would just take train to Naples.

We took the train from Rome to Naples. Business class seats give you more space to keep luggage nearby, and a porter comes through with a beverage/snack cart (included with your ticket). Then we had a private driver from Naples to Sorrento, with a stop in Pompeii for a few hours. He kept our luggage in the car and stayed with it while we had a guided tour. We used Autoservizi De Martino and were very happy with their service.
We took the train fromRome to Naples. Business class as well. It’s not that long of a ride. Driver was there to pick us up. Worked great. We were a group of 7 seniors.
Can anyone recommend a private driver from Rome Airport to Sorrento and if so some idea of price? Thank you
Train from Rome to Naples and local train from Naples to Sorrento is what we did

It's a 3.5 hour drive, so a private driver would certainly not be cheap. I would personally opt for a high-speed train from Rome to Naples, but you'd first have to take a train into Rome. From Naples to Sorrento, you have several options.

text: Bonjourno any tips on what to see in Naples in self ?

comments.comment_text:
Naples : Capodimonte and San Elmo, Via Toledo, Duomo, Chiostro Di Santa Chiara, Lungomare, Castel dell'Ovo, Teatro San Carlo, Palazzo Reale, Piazza del Plebiscito, Monte della Misericordia, Capella San Severo. Taste gelato at Gay Odin, pizza portafoglio, pizza frita, fiori di zucca fritti, sfogliatella. Train to Pompei. Ferry to Ischia, Procida, Capri.

Costiera amalfitana : Sorrento as a base. Go to : Positano, Amalfi, Ravello. The roads are usually busy, better with the ferry. Hike on the path of Gods. You can also take the ferry to visit the islands from there.

Pizza 🍕 Pizza 🍕
Actually a trip to Cassertas the old Royal Residence is definitely worth a trip

Castell dell’ovo
San Severo monastery ,
Spaccanapoli , Via Toledo, teatro San Carlo, palazzo reale piazza pebliscito, via Caracciolo, quartiere riviera chiaia, Vomero district, castel Sant’Elmo, Certosa Museo di San Martino, museo nazionale train 🚂
National Archeological museum
Eat, as much as you can. Then board the ferry to Capri ⛵
Pizza and I went to Pompeii by train for a day… Shopping and food are cheap in Naples….

There was a wonderful little place where they make Limoncello, alongside another store where they hand carve intricate cameos.(like the necklaces). It was very interesting. The Limoncello Cream was absolutely delicious!

It s still written BUONGIORNO, anyway;)
We Italians don't write HELOO when we arrive in the Us.;)
San Martino (up the funicular), duomo, next door to duomo is a church with a Caravaggio, archaeological museum, veiled Christ, catacombs, any church you pass. Casertes palace north of the city
I loved the Palazzo Reale and the gardens. Walking the Lungomare Caracciolo at sunset was beautiful.

If you like football.
How about a Naples game in the Maradona stadium 🏟
The Cristo Velato.
Maradona murals.

text:
Hello, planning our honeymoon for Sept 2024 we aim to fly into Rome and spend 10 days in Italy, feedback on the below would be amazing! We love food, wine and scenery! 🍷🏞
Fly London to Rome - 3 nights
Drive Rome to Florence - 4 nights - inc day trip to Tuscany, Cinque Terre. Would it be better to split and spend 2 nights in Tuscany? Is Cinque Terre… आणखी worth the hype, I have seen alot of mixed reviews within this group.
Drive Florence to Dolomites - 3 nights - Day 1 - visit Tre Cime di Laveredo and Cadini peaks, Day 2 - Lago di Braies, Santa Magdalena, Lago di Carezza, Day 3 - Alpe di siusi - recommendations on the best areas to stay for Day 1 and Day 2?
After the Dolomites we would drive to Switzerland.

comments.comment_text: So much to see in Tuscany, split and spend 2 days there and in my opinion, Cinque Terre is definitely worth it, please walk between two towns, the views, the vineyards, I tend to hear people catch trains and don’t do at least one walk, they are missing out. Vernazza to Manarola was awesome. Great time of year to go, not hot!

If you go to Tuscany, stick around Siena and the Val d'Orcia.It s the real Tuscan landscapes: vineyards on the hills, cypress, quaint villages.
Try Chiostro di Pienza in Pienza (former convent of the 1500's with Italian garden and pool) and Bagno Vignoni (natural spa waters at Posta Marcucci hotel) plus Montalcino etc
I would take a train rather than drive.

Day 2 in the Dolomites is impossible if you want to see something. It is quite a long drive from lago di Braies to lago di Carezza. You can not drive fast in tje mountains. Stay the first 2 days in the Dolomites in Bruneck ans then go close to alpe di siusi, for instans Seis, or Castelrotto. You won’ regret going to the Dolomites.
Tuscany is worth spending time in it’s stunning

We stayed Vernazza..aweso
me!!

We just did similar trip. Flew into Rome, stayed 2 nights, 2 nights in Lucca, 3 nights Cinque Terres, 3 nights rural Tuscany, 1 night Florence, 3 nights Sirmione (Lake Garda) then 2 nights Venice. Loved every spot, especially Lucca and Sirmione. Feel free to reach out with any questions.

Definitely split Florence/
Tuscany/CT. Make sure to get to CT earlier in the day so you have time to go to a town or two that day, and then hit the others the next day. It totally depends what kind of vacation you want – – we wanted something more laid-back, so spent less time in Florence (even though there is a ton to see there.). Personally ￼ I would do one night in Florence, 2 nights in Tuscany, 1 night in CT.

Hi, I think you are underestimating
the distances😅
Cinque terre are amazing especially in off season like September. But it’s not worth it as a day trip in my opinion as the journey to/from Tuscany can be long (3h each leg) and then you’ll need extra time to go from one terra from another.
The trip from Florence to dolomites takes more than 5 hours, and then you’ll need 1-2 hours a day to visits all the places you’ve mentioned.
I think it depends on what you want to do and if you don’t mind spending a lot of your time driving😅
Shelby Britton

Don't do a day trip to Cinque Terre. If you can, stay there for a night or two. The towns completely transform after 5PM when all the day trippers and cruise ship peeps leave....and it's truly amazing.
Pick up your rental car as you LEAVE Firenze
A car is more trouble than it’s worth in Florence, absolutely not needed

text:
Hoping someone can help
We are at Bellagio now and looking at some 18ct gold crosses
The prices seem cheap for what I was expecting
Would it be possible they aren’t real?
Surely not??
It’s a shop on the lake front🤷‍♀️

comments.comment_text: Gold is about $2000 per ounce. Ask if it is solid gold, gold platted, gold dipped, or silver and then platted.

18 ct gold prices per gm are around 42/45 euros.
Check weight and calculate accordingly… and definitely look for the hallmark and authenticity certification

Check for the stamp on it, the jewellery shops on the front are all legit, there's Rose Maria, lovely shop, then another one a couple of shops up from her and then along towards the car ferry is a bigger shop that sells lovely jewellery along with antique china and vases etc.
When we were in a Murano shop, we were warned that many of the” Murano” goods are actually made in China. If you’re headed to Venice, buy in Murano itself.

Careful of Murano as some comes from China
Buy in Murano itself

I found an 18k necklace I loved in the N.Lake area, & I’m sorry I let it go. If you love it, get it! Yes, you want to be sure it is the quality they are stating, but after that, how much cheaper can you get it should not be the final decision, your love of it should. When I went to Venice, everything was more $$
Love Bellagio..
Always pay with a credit card. This way if you find out it was not authentic you can always dispute the charge. Amex is the best for this if it’s accepted at the shop.

I decided against it considering they got annoyed with me and took the magnifier that she gave me away haha
Thanks everyone
Too cheap to be gold. Gold is very expensive, especially 18k.
It might be 18 ct but it could be hollow. I bought a 14 ct gold bracelet and it broke within 2 months bc it was hollow.
The price of gold is currently about1,750 euros a gram.
We were just there. I don’t think it is fine jewelry. They sent me to another shop for solid gold.

Just visited Murano and the glass blowing museum and was told by one of the incredible salesman/
employees that 99.9% of all of the items sold in the Venice shops that are advertised as being from Murano are not real and imported from allover- when you buy from the gallery in Murano you’re given a certificate of authenticity along with free shipping & a warranty! Hope this helps 😊

I was hoping to purchase a Mary pendant, don't need the necklace, what would you expect to pay? I'm going to Firenze and Positano

If it’s 18k gold there should be a stamp of the number 750 if it’s 14k which you will most likely not see in Italy it should say 585. If you see 925 on the stamp then it’s silver. These numbers represent the percentage of alloy to the actual medal. So 18k is 75% gold and 25% various types of alloy
Is this the woman? I bought a ring from her for my granddaughter and it turned her finger green. Not 14k as I was assured.
Sounds gold coated only
Certainly not any place that I would buy "good" jewelry!! And, the only place that I would buy Murano would be in Murano from a studio!!
If in doubt, which you are, don't buy!
!!! Genuine Murano glass is always marked with the "Verti Di Murano" certificate of authenticity.
I didn’t find Murano cheap. But if you’re asking about a glass dish for 20 euros maybe that’s cheaper than $80.
Beware of fake crap from China.

The 24k gold price is around 62ish usd,if it’s too good to be true,chances are it’s not real

As a jeweler I’ve seen many fake souvenir “jewellery”,som
etimes the gold content is less than 25%,sometimes the stones are stuffed with tissue paper to make it look bigger,sometime
s they use base metal shank inside the ring to reduce the gold usage…

Gold is at 2000 US dollars per Troy ounce on the global market currently.

If you like it buy it when I was there last year I saw a beautiful little cross kept looking at it every time I passed by one of the glass cabinets on the wall I left it too long and some one else bought it lesson learned going again for three weeks to Bellagio in September for the wine festival And on to Venice for 2 weeks so hopefully I can shop in both places
Ask them…also, they would be stamp he’d in the back 18K.
Whilst I appreciate quality and authenticity matter, at end of the day do you like it? Are you happy with the price? It’s still a souvenir bought in Italy.

I was just in BELLAGIO and was on the water promenade in a very nice jewelry store. It was a pretty big store, but I can’t remember the name of it and it did look legitimate. Make sure it’s not silver plated and dipped it should be solid gold ask them that at least.
Monica, ask the jeweler for authenticity ! If they can’t provide it then don’t buy 👎
Honestly, if was my understanding that authentic Murano glass has a very specific label indicating that it was handmade. I think it’s a white rectangle
At the current price per ounce of gold I would be asking the jeweller the weight of the cross and I imagine you'll find it is gold plated rather than solid gold at that price.

In regards to gold that doesn’t seem cheap to me. But I don’t wear gold
According to European law, all gold has to be hallmarked. Look for the hallmarks- 750 for 18ct
In Italy, gold is always marked. A 18 ct object must have 750 engraved somewhere, otherwise it's either coated or fake.

text:
Wow-the pictures on here are just stunning. I’ve just recently joined this group as I’ve never been to Italy but am harbouring a longing to plan a three week trip- probably April 2025.
However, I’m gluten free and dairy free. I’d love it someone could let me know what the restaurants are like in terms of catering for this?

comments.comment_text: In Florence now. Came from Rome yesterday. In my experience the menus in most restaurants have codes listed for all the different food allergies, etc. Even on a vineyard tour they gave options. Very accomodating!
In Italy it s mandatory for every menu to have listed ingredients for people with allergies.

There is a facebook page called Gluten Free Italy. There are plenty of options literally everywhere when you get there. We were there 13 years ago never had an issue finding something gluten free to eat and we will go again this year 🙂 they list their allergens

Pick an area
... type your requests into the net and I don't doubt sites like tripadvisor will come up with 100s of reviews for food intolerance restaurants

Gluten intollerance is also an Italian health issue and there are many options, at least in major cities, just check recommendations
on social media or Google.

It depends if you are allergic to gluten or intolerant. Some dishes are gluten free (e.g. some friend food), but the allergene might show up in the menu due to cross contamination. You will alm ostonly find dairy free cheeses at vegan restaurants. Dairy free milks almost everywhere. If you go to Rome try Rifugio Romano, it is a vegan restaurant, they have gluten free options, but they do serve traditional Italian recipes, so it is a good compromise if you travel with people who are not intolerant/
vegan and want to try local food.
Honestly I found pasta and pizza in Italy no problems!!! I’m convinced their flour is not genetically modified like ours. Had no indigestion or bowel problems
Italy is right up there with up to date information on food intolerances. Plenty of gluten free options everywhere. Have fun planning your trip!
Are you a Celiac. intolerant or just avoiding gluten?

text: What is the best on line tour group to use when booking for the colosseum and Vatican for a trip in September?

comments.comment_text: There are sooo many options, depending on how much you want to see in each place. When we were looking we decided what and how much we want to see and then looked who offers what we want
I recommend you only Coopculture for Colosseum and Vatican Museums for Vatican. Hard to secure as requires planning and effort but only way to guarantee you get what you book.
Coop culture website issues tickets 30 days before. So keep an eye on the website, do a practice run! Tricky but I managed to get 5 for the night time tour last September
